feed.title: NewsTracker: netanyahu
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Netanyahu slams Palestinians over Israel boycott campaign
entry.summary:
Netanyahu made the comments Sunday at a meeting of his new Cabinet just two days after a Palestinian proposal to suspend Israel from world football was dropped at the last moment.

Netanyahu warned that such efforts to boycott Israel continue.

Netanyahu said that he was pleased the Palestinian attempt to have Israel suspended from FIFA, world soccer's governing body, was rebuffed in the end, but warned that Israel will face similar boycott efforts in the future.

entry.title: Netanyahu says committed to Palestinian state
entry.summary: "I think the only way to move that is through direct negotiations. Unfortunately, the Palestinian Authority has moved away from these negotiations," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu calls on Palestinian Authority to return to negotiating table
entry.summary:
Germany's Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem.

Speaking after talks with visiting German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier on Sunday, Mr Netanyahu said he was committed to the establishment of a Palestinian state, calling on the Palestinian leadership to return to negotiations unconditionally.

Mr Netanyahu sparked international concern when he ruled out the establishment of a Palestinian state while campaigning for the March 17 general election but later backtracked on the comments.

entry.title: Netanyahu offers to resume peace talks with settlement focus, official says
entry.summary: One Western diplomat familiar with what occurred at the meeting with Mogherini said Netanyahu's proposal showed some change in his position, but not enough to restart peace talks.

entry.title: Netanyahu offers to resume peace talks with settlement focus, official says
entry.summary:
It could also appease hardliners in Netanyahu's government who want to see more construction.

Another Western diplomat described Netanyahu's proposal as creating "the illusion of progress".

entry.title: Netanyahu offers Palestinians peace talks based on current settlement blocs: report
entry.summary:
An Israeli newspaper says Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has offered to renew peace talks with the Palestinians.

Netanyahu, at a minimum, wants to keep major settlement blocs within Israel's separation barrier.

Palestinian Foreign Minister Riad al-Malki says Netanyahu is "trying to deceive the world with his meaningless talk."

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu picks long-time supporter Dore Gold for Israeli foreign ministry
entry.summary: With the Obama administration having promised to reassess its defense of Israel in international forums, in large part because of questions over Mr Netanyahu's commitment to a Palestinian state, some analysts thought the prime minister would try to put a friendlier, centrist face on his foreign policy.

entry.title: New Netanyahu government wins MPs' approval as Obama urges deal
entry.summary:
"We will safeguard our security and strive for peace," Netanyahu said in a speech ahead of the parliamentary vote, which was interrupted by loud laughter from the opposition and heckling from Arab Israeli lawmakers, three of whom were ejected.

After two months of coalition horse-trading, Thursday's session was delayed for another two hours to give Netanyahu more time to placate senior members of his Likud party.

entry.title: Obama not enthused by some members of Netanyahu's government
Israel's parliament approves new Netanyahu government
entry.summary: Likud members were handed portfolios in talks with Netanyahu that lasted into the Thursday parliamentary session.

entry.title: Embattled from the outset, new Netanyahu government sworn in
entry.summary:
Seconds into his speech unveiling the government, as he pledged that it would "safeguard security, work toward peace," Netanyahu was interrupted by opposition heckling and guffaws.

"I am leaving the door open for broadening the government," Netanyahu said in his speech.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu finalises cabinet lineup for vote
entry.summary:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was preparing on Thursday to present his proposed government for the approval of parliament, where his coalition commands a razor-thin majority.

Netanyahu confidant Ofir Akunis will be a junior minister in the ministry of communications, which will be headed by the prime minister himself, a party spokesman said.

entry.title: Israeli parliament votes to expand number of ministers
entry.summary:
JERUSALEM (AP) - Israel's parliament has approved a contentious legislation that expands the number of government ministers - clearing the way for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's new government to take office.

Netanyahu is now expected to appoint his new Cabinet, with the government to be sworn into office in the coming days.

entry.title: Israeli parliament approves expanded number of ministers in boost to Prime Minister Netanyahu
entry.summary: But under pressure from his new coalition partners, Netanyahu agreed to expand the size of his Cabinet again.

entry.title: Walker tweets out meeting with Netanyahu
entry.summary: Thanks @netanyahu for the meeting.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu completes formation of government
entry.summary:
Netanyahu reached a deal with the nationalist Jewish Home party shortly before a midnight deadline, clinching a slim parliamentary majority and averting an embarrassing scenario that would have forced him from office.

Netanyahu had until midnight to speak to Rivlin.

Netanyahu's Likud Party is dominated by hard-liners opposed to Palestinian independence, a position that is shared by the Jewish Home.

entry.title: Netanyahu forms new government just ahead of deadline
Israel's Netanyahu completes formation of government
Israel's Netanyahu clinches deal for new coalition government - sources
entry.summary: The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Netanyahu's Likud party and the Jewish Home had plans to announce the deal shortly and then sign it.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu clinches deal for new coalition government - sources
Israel's Netanyahu reportedly close to forming coalition
entry.summary:
A last-minute deal with the hawkish Jewish Home Party was necessary to prevent an almost-unimaginable scenario by which Netanyahu would be forced out of office.

But even if they reach a deal, Netanyahu would have a thin majority, leaving him vulnerable to the demands of any individual coalition lawmaker.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu reportedly close to forming coalition
entry.summary: Israeli TV stations said Netanyahu's Likud and the Jewish Home were closing in on a deal that would give the Jewish Home control of the influential Justice Ministry.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu races to form narrow coalition government
entry.summary: That left Netanyahu dependent on Jewish Home leader Naftali Bennett, a former aide who has a rocky relationship with Netanyahu.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu reportedly close to forming coalition
Netanyahu's efforts to form Israeli government go down to wire
entry.summary: JERUSALEM: Benjamin Netanyahu, locked in down-to-the-wire coalition talks, faces a midnight deadline to form a government or risk being denied a fourth term as Israel's prime minister.

entry.title: Netanyahu's efforts to form Israeli government go down to wire
Israel's Netanyahu races to form narrow coalition government
entry.summary: Netanyahu was holding furious consultations Wednesday with the hawkish Jewish Home Party in order to secure a narrow 61-seat majority in the 120-seat parliament.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu races to form narrow coalition government
entry.summary: With a little over 24 hours to go, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is scrambling to get his governing coalition together.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu scrambles to form governing coalition
entry.summary:
JERUSALEM - With the clock ticking, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu raced to put together a governing coalition Tuesday or face the prospect of being forced out of office by a former ally.

With the deadline approaching, Netanyahu negotiated Tuesday with the hawkish Jewish Home Party.

The party, linked to the West Bank settler movement, is led by Naftali Bennett, a former Netanyahu aide who now has a rocky relationship with him.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Scrambles to Form Governing Coalition
entry.summary: By late Tuesday, Netanyahu had deals with three partners controlling 53 seats.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu scrambles to form governing coalition
entry.summary: Netanyahu has had a tough time striking deals with potential partners to form a majority coalition in the 120-seat parliament.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Scrambles to Form Governing Coalition
entry.summary: Netanyahu hit a snag Monday when a key ally, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman, unexpectedly resigned and announced his party is joining the opposition.

entry.title: Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu embraces Ethiopian Jew victim of videotaped police beating
entry.summary:
Jerusalem: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has expressed shock over a videotaped police beating of an Ethiopian Israeli man, and promised action to improve relations with the Ethiopian Jewish community.

Elsewhere, Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman announced on Monday that he will not join Mr Netanyahu's government, dealing a blow to the incumbent's emerging coalition in the 11th hour of negotiations.

entry.title: Israel's Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman snubs Netanyahu coalition invite
entry.summary: According to recent local media reports, Mr Lieberman holds a grudge against Mr Netanyahu, blaming him for an ongoing police investigation into allegations of corruption by senior members of his party.

entry.title: Israel's Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman snubs Netanyahu coalition invite
entry.summary: Mr Netanyahu still has a good chance of presenting his fourth government by the deadline.

entry.title: Israel's Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman snubs Netanyahu coalition invite
entry.summary:
Defying predictions, Mr Netanyahu's right-wing, nationalist Likud won 30 seats in the March 17 election, paving the way for him to serve a fourth term in office as premier.

The next Netanyahu government would not be a nationalist one, "but the personification of opportunism", he charged.

entry.title: Israeli foreign minister steps down to join opposition
entry.summary:
Without Yisrael Beitenu, Netanyahu is expected to have a slim majority of just 61 seats, leaving him susceptible to the demands of partners.

Last week, Netanyahu signed up his first two partners, the center-right Kulanu party, led by influential newcomer Moshe Kahlon, and the ultra-Orthodox party United Torah Judaism.

Netanyahu is also expected to team up with Shas, another ultra-Orthodox party, and the nationalist Jewish Home party.

He later quit Netanyahu's Likud party and was elected to parliament in 1999 as head of Yisrael Beitenu, a secular hawkish party he established to represent the more than 1 million immigrants from the former Soviet Union.

entry.title: News24.com | Netanyahu signs first partners in new coalition
entry.summary:
Jerusalem - Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu signed up his first partners on Wednesday for a new coalition government, a lawmaker and spokesperson said, putting him on course to lead a heavily right-leaning cabinet.

Netanyahu's emerging government is likely to pursue tough policies towards the Palestinians, including further settlement building in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem, lands the Palestinians seek for a state along with the Gaza Strip.

Jewish Home is a pro-settler party which advocates the annexation of most the West Bank, a policy Netanyahu has not embraced but which some Likud members support.

entry.title: Netanyahu signs first partners in new Israeli coalition
entry.summary: The deals with the ultra-Orthodox United Torah Judaism (UTJ) party and centrist Kulanu give Netanyahu's right-wing Likud control of 46 of parliament's 120 seats.

entry.title: Israel PM Benjamin Netanyahu given 14 more days to form coalition government
entry.summary: Mr Netanyahu is pursuing a government with hawkish, religious and centrist parties that will give him a coalition representing at least 61 members of Israel's 120-seat parliament, or Knesset, though he hopes for the more comfortable backing of 67 lawmakers.

entry.title: Netanyahu receives two-week extension to form government
entry.summary:
"We made progress and we are on the way to forming a government, but I need additional time for it to be stable and to reach agreements on important issues that will help us meet all the challenges facing Israel," Netanyahu said during a meeting with President Reuven Rivlin.

Their slow pace has raised speculation that Netanyahu, who would serve a fourth term as prime minister, could opt for a broader coalition with Zionist Union.

If Netanyahu fails to win the support of at least 61 legislators in the next two weeks - a scenario political commentators see as unlikely - Rivlin can ask another member of parliament to try to put together a government.

entry.title: Israeli leader gets 2-week extension to form coalition
entry.summary:
Netanyahu told the Israeli president he has made progress in negotiations with potential partners but needs more time to form a stable coalition.

Netanyahu looks close to finalizing deals with two ultra-Orthodox parties and the centrist, economics-focused Kulanu party.

But large gaps remain with two nationalist parties led by long-time Netanyahu associates.

Israeli President Reuven Rivlin granted Netanyahu the extension Monday.

entry.title: Despite victory, Israeli PM Netanyahu struggling to form coalition
entry.summary: So far Herzog's party rank-and-file seems to oppose joining Netanyahu and appears eager to watch a hard-line government fail.

entry.title: Despite victory, Israeli leader struggling to form coalition
entry.summary:
But after weeks of negotiations with potential partners, Netanyahu is finding the task harder than expected and is flirting with the idea of reaching out to his main dovish rivals to form a unity government.

Tsahi Hanegbi, the deputy foreign minister from Netanyahu's Likud Party, said the prospect of Herzog joining the coalition was only becoming a possibility due to the hard-ball approach of the right-wing parties.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu speaks to Putin, protests Russian plans to sell advanced missiles to Iran
entry.summary:
Benjamin Netanyahu's office says he spoke with Vladimir Putin Tuesday to protest Russia's planned delivery of advanced S-300 air defense missile systems to the Islamic Republic.

Netanyahu says he told Putin the move would only increase Iran's aggression in the region and undermine security in the Middle East.

entry.title: ?Netanyahu?s biggest fear? That Iran ?honors nuclear deal?
entry.summary: "Netanyahu said at the meeting that it would be impossible to catch the Iranians cheating simply because they will not break the agreement," one of the officials told Haaretz.

entry.title: Iran must end 'aggression' for sanctions relief: Netanyahu
entry.summary:
But Netanyahu, whose government has repeatedly denounced the framework agreement as an "historic mistake", said any such move should be linked to other issues.

"To my regret, all of the things I warned about vis-a-vis the framework agreement that was put together in Lausanne are coming true before our eyes," Netanyahu's office quoted him as saying, referring to the Swiss city where the framework deal was agreed.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says sanctions should remain on Iran
entry.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu has harshly criticized the U.S.-led framework deal with Iran, which offers relief from sanctions in exchange for scaling back its suspect nuclear program.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says sanctions should remain on Iran
entry.summary: Netanyahu said Sunday that a better deal would tie the lifting of all sanctions, "to an end of Iran's aggression in the region, its worldwide terrorism and its threats to annihilate Israel."

entry.title: Iran cannot be trusted, Netanyahu warns
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu kept up his assault on the framework nuclear deal between world powers and Iran, warning late Saturday that the Islamic republic could not be trusted.

entry.title: Gov. Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary: Walker said his goal is to meet with Netanyahu and other members of the Israeli government to get an understanding of the issues facing the Middle East.

entry.title: Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary:
Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker says he "absolutely" expects to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during his first visit to Israel next month.

Walker, a Republican, told The Associated Press in an interview ahead of his departure on a European trade mission that the Netanyahu meeting in mid-May is not yet confirmed, but that it's his "hope and expectation" it will happen.

entry.title: Netanyahu seeks better deal on Iran
entry.summary: Obama, whose relations with Netanyahu have frayed badly over the Iran issue, sought to assure Israelis he understands their concerns.

entry.title: Netanyahu seeks better deal on Iran; Obama says it is best hope on nuclear issue
entry.summary: Netanyahu said he has spoken with both Democrats and Republicans in Congress - nearly two thirds of House of Representatives members and a similar number in the U.S. Senate - about the Iran nuclear issue.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Nuke deal enables Iran "terror machine"
entry.summary: "[T]hat is: standing firm, ratcheting up the pressure, until you get a better deal," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu once again blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: "It doesn't roll back Iran's nuclear program," Netanyahu said, one of several US networks he appeared on to slam the deal.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran
entry.summary: Netanyahu denied he was coordinating with House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner, who visited Israel last week, and with other Republicans to block the Iran deal.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran: CNN
Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: Netanyahu, whose hard-line rhetoric taps into Mizrahi disdain for the Arabs who mistreated them in their countries of origin, "speaks not only fluent English, but also fluent Mizrahi," wrote Avi Issacharoff in the Times of Israel website.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: The Hebrew on the photo reads: "Choosing Prime Minister, only Likud only Netanyahu".

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary:
Mizrahi, or Middle Eastern, Jews heavily backed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party, while Ashkenazi, or European, Jews mostly identified with the opposition Zionist Union.

Since Netanyahu's win, the sides have been exchanging insults that have not been heard in public in a generation - with the Mizrahi voters accused of being primitive and Ashkenazi voters viewed as elitist.

They also often argue that Netanyahu's hard-line policies toward the Palestinians prevent a peace agreement that would bring on an economic boom that would benefit Mizrahim.

Yet voting patterns from this month's election indicate that Netanyahu largely owes his re-election to the last-minute mobilization of Likud's Mizrahi supporters.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: Many had pledged to turn their back on Likud to protest its economic policies or because of disdain for Netanyahu's lengthy rule and perceived decadent lifestyle.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Iran must recognize Israel's right to exist
entry.summary: " ... I want to make clear to all: The survival of Israel is non-negotiable," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Says His Cabinet United in 'Strongly Opposing' Proposed Iran Nuclear Deal
Nuclear deal threatens Israel's existence, Benjamin Netanyahu says
Iran nuclear deal threatens Israel's existence, Benjamin Netanyahu tells President Obama
entry.summary: "This deal would legitimize Iran's nuclear programme, bolster Iran's economy and increase Iran's aggression and terror throughout the Middle East and beyond," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Deal must 'significantly' curb Iran nuke program
entry.summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been a leading critic of the nuclear talks, which aim to curb Iran's suspect nuclear program.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Deal must 'significantly' curb Iran nuke program
entry.summary:
Netanyahu has said he believes the deal, which must be finalized in the coming months, will leave too much of Iran's nuclear infrastructure intact.

"Any deal must significantly roll back Iran's nuclear capabilities and stop its terrorism and aggression," Netanyahu said on Twitter, minutes before the announcement from Lausanne.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Boehner hail 'strong' US, Israel ties
entry.summary: Boehner caused a furore earlier this year when he invited Netanyahu to address a joint session of Congress on the Iran talks, without consulting the White House.

entry.title: World must insist on 'better' Iran deal: Netanyahu
entry.summary: To Netanyahu, a "better deal" would "significantly roll back Iran's nuclear infrastructure" as well as "link the eventual lifting of the restrictions on Iran's nuclear program to a change in Iran's behaviour."

entry.title: News24.com | Netanyahu: Iran deal will allow nuclear breakout
entry.summary: "It appears the deal being formed in Lausanne will leave Iran with underground facilities, the nuclear reactor in Arak and with advanced centrifuges," Netanyahu said at a parliamentary ceremony.

entry.title: Lausanne deal would pave way for nuclear-armed Iran: Netanyahu
entry.summary: The deal being hammered out between world powers and Iran on its nuclear programme would "pave the way" to a nuclear-armed Tehran, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday.

entry.title: Disputes emerge as Netanyahu starts work on new Israel govt
entry.summary:
For now, Netanyahu's focus is likely to be squarely on the marathon talks between his right-wing Likud and the five parties endorsing his premiership.

Representatives of the four other parties met with Likud's negotiating team throughout the day, with statements from Netanyahu's party providing no details.

Since the election, Netanyahu has sought to backtrack on his remarks on a Palestinian state, and issued a public apology to the Arab community.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu asked to form Israel's government
entry.summary:
Israeli law does not oblige the president to assign the task of forming the government to the party that won the largest share of votes, in this case Mr Netanyahu's Likud.

He also called on Mr Netanyahu to restore public trust in the political system, after the outgoing government collapsed and turbulent elections were held two years ahead of schedule.

Mr Netanyahu will have several weeks to negotiate with potential members of his coalition to reconcile demands over appointments and ideological positions and ensure a stable government.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Takes Conciliatory Tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu's comments appeared to be aimed at repairing the damage caused by comments he made in the final days of the campaign that strained relations with the U.S. and drew accusations of racism from the country's Arab minority.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Seeking to shore up support among his hard-line voters in the final hours of the campaign, Netanyahu said he would not allow the establishment of a Palestinian state on his watch and warned that Arab voters were heading to the polls "in droves."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu spoke at a ceremony where the country's president, Reuven Rivlin, officially handed him the task of forming the next government.

entry.title: Netanyahu gets go-ahead to form Israel's next government
entry.summary:
President Reuven Rivlin had some uncharacteristic criticism of Netanyahu as he went through the formality of handing him a mandate to establish a new government, having verified with party leaders that a majority supported him.

Netanyahu's pre-election promise that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch and his comments about Arab voters further aggravated his testy relationship with U.S. President Barack Obama, who has dismissed his subsequent attempts to backtrack.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu's Likud Party captured 30 seats in last week's national election, making it the largest party in the 120-seat parliament.

entry.title: Netanyahu to form next government after US spat
entry.summary:
In a bid to ramp up votes, Netanyahu veered sharply to the right, vowing there would be no Palestinian state on his watch, promising to increase settlement construction and warning that Arab Israeli voters were going "in droves" to the polls.

"We believe that two states is the best path forward for Israel's security, for Palestinian aspirations and for regional stability... Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach."

Several hours before Obama's remarks, the Wall Street Journal published a report in which US officials accused Israel of spying on nuclear negotiations with Iran aimed at reaching a deal that Netanyahu opposes.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Putin on same 'businesslike' level with Obama
entry.summary: Relations have cooled further since Netanyahu has been vocal in his criticism of the nuclear talks with Iran and since he declared that a Palestinian state would not be created as long as he was prime minister.

entry.title: Obama describes relations with Netanyahu as 'businesslike,' same term used for Putin
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON - When it comes to relations with President Barack Obama, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been - elevated is not quite the right word - placed in rare company.

That appears to put Netanyahu on a par with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The vibe between Netanyahu and Obama has never been one of close friends.

So at least with Netanyahu, Obama kept the relationship description at "very businesslike."

entry.title: Netanyahu, Putin on same 'businesslike' level with Obama
Obama: Differences with Israel's Netanyahu not personal
Obama: Netanyahu statements don't clarify two-state solution
entry.summary: Netanyahu has decried the talks, saying they are leading to a deal that would place Israel at risk.

entry.title: Obama: Netanyahu statements don't clarify two-state solution
entry.summary: He said he has a "businesslike" relationship with Netanyahu, and has met with him more than any other world leader.

entry.title: Obama: Prospect for Palestinian state still unclear despite Netanyahu's clarifications
entry.summary:
He acknowledged that Netanyahu later pointed out that he did not say a Palestinian state would "never" be created.

Obama noted a tendency in reporting to frame the current dispute as a personal issue between Netanyahu and Obama.

entry.title: Obama: Netanyahu statements don't clarify two-state solution
Arab-Israeli political leaders reject Netanyahu's apology
entry.summary: Emilie Moatti, a spokeswoman for the Joint List, said the Arab dignitaries who gathered at Netanyahu's home were all Likud supporters, with no Joint List representatives invited.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli political leaders reject Netanyahu's apology
entry.summary: Netanyahu told a gathering of Arab dignitaries Monday, "I know that what I said a few days ago offended some of Israel's citizens, offended Israeli Arabs. I had no intention of doing so. I am sorry for this."

entry.title: Arab-Israeli leaders reject Netanyahu's apology for offending Arabs in election-day comment
entry.summary: Arab politicians said his election victory was illegitimate, claiming Netanyahu won the vote by pandering to anti-Arab fears.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli political leaders reject Netanyahu's apology
entry.summary: Arab-Israeli politician Ahmed Tibi told Israel Radio Tuesday that Netanyahu's attempt to defuse the dispute was "not an honest apology."

entry.title: Majority winner Netanyahu apologises to Arab Israelis
entry.summary: "His excuses are not acceptable because not only does Benjamin Netanyahu plan to bring in racist legislation but his words challenged the very right of Arab Israelis to vote for the Knesset," Israel's parliament, he said on television.

entry.title: Top Obama aide: US can't ignore Netanyahu's comments
entry.summary: On Monday, Netanyahu apologized to Israel's Arab citizens for another set of remarks that offended members of the community and drew additional U.S. criticism.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary: But President Barack Obama's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, rejected Netanyahu's attempt to distance himself from his comments, telling an Israel advocacy group Monday that the U.S. can't just overlook what Netanyahu said on the eve of his re-election.

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he 'regrets' election-day rallying call
entry.summary: JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday he regretted offending Israel's Arabs during a rallying call on election day last week that his critics had denounced as racist.

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he "regrets" election-day rallying call
entry.summary: In a video clip posted on his Facebook page, Netanyahu told representatives of Israel's Arab community: "I know that the things I said a few days ago offended Israel's Arabs. I had no intention for this to happen, I regret this."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary: Netanyahu drew accusations of racism in Israel, especially from its Arab minority, and a White House rebuke when, just a few hours before polling stations were to close across the country, he warned that Arab citizens were voting "in droves."

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he 'regrets' election-day rallying call
Israel?s Netanyahu Apologizes to Country?s Arab Minority
entry.summary: Netanyahu, whose Likud Party won re-election in the vote, met with members of the Arab community at the prime minister's residence in Jerusalem on Monday and apologized.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build coalition
entry.summary:
It became a formality after the new centrist party Kulanu gave its nod to Netanyahu as well, giving him 61 backers out of the 120 in parliament.

Rivlin is scheduled to meet with Netanyahu later this week and officially set the coalition talks into motion.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build new coalition after securing majority backing
entry.summary: Netanyahu appears poised to set up a coalition with Kulanu and several religious and ultra-Orthodox parties.

entry.title: For Liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's Win Is a Reality Check
entry.summary:
But as the results trickled in on Wednesday, they showed Likud with a shocking lead that has all but guaranteed Netanyahu a third consecutive term.

Social media was full of embittered Israelis accusing Netanyahu's supporters of racism, and some vowed to stop donating charity to the underprivileged whom they perceived as being automatic supporters of the right.

entry.title: U.S. to ?reassess? options following Netanyahu?s remarks
entry.summary:
A spokesman in Netanyahu's office declined to comment on the conversation with Obama.

In a pre-election interview with an Israeli news site, Netanyahu answered "indeed" when asked directly whether there would be no Palestinian state if he were to win another term as prime minister.

entry.title: Netanyahu row casts doubt on Obama pledge to 'have Israel's back'
Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's ties to Obama hit new low
entry.summary: House Speaker John Boehner is heading to Israel as already strained relations between the White House and newly re-elected Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hit a new low this week.

entry.title: Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's ties to Obama hit new low
entry.summary: Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his re-election, but also told the Israeli leader that the U.S. is reassessing its approach to Israeli-Palestinian peace in light of his comments about a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel more excluded after election
entry.summary: Asked by NPR if he would engage in fence-mending, given how his remarks were received, Netanyahu said: "Well, I certainly will make sure that everybody understands that I'm the prime minister of all of Israel's citizens, and I really believe that. It's something that my actions have shown. It's not a question of fence-mending, it's a question of real belief, and it's there. I don't have to fabricate it."

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel more excluded after election
entry.summary:
The election, in which Netanyahu eventually secured his fourth term, highlighted the fraught relationship between Israel's Arab citizens and the Jewish state.

In what was seen as an attempt to galvanize his hard-line supporters during Tuesday's election, Netanyahu had warned that "Arab voters are going in droves to the polls," with the help of "left-wing" activists.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel a greater sense of exclusion following Netanyahu election win
entry.summary:
Netanyahu has signaled he will set up a government of right-wing and religious parties.

Netanyahu, defending his record amid widespread criticism of his election-day remarks, told NBC that his government has spent "billions" in Arab towns to upgrade infrastructure and schools.

entry.title: House Speaker Boehner to travel to Israel
entry.summary: Asked whether Obama got a better understanding of Netanyahu's position on a Palestinian state after talking with him, White House spokesman Josh Earnest said Friday: "That was not the result of the call."

entry.title: Relations with US strained as Netanyahu seizes power
entry.summary:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu touches the Western Wall in Jerusalem, after winning the general election on Wednesday.

Copies of ballot papers and campaign posters for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party abandoned after the nation's elections on Wednesday.

entry.title: US to 'reassess' options with Israel, Barack Obama tells Benjamin Netanyahu
Obama congratulates Netanyahu on election in phone call
entry.summary: The call came as the White House continued to push back against Netanyahu's pre-election rejection of a two-state solution to Palestinian-Israeli peace.

entry.title: Obama congratulates Netanyahu on election in phone call
In Netanyahu call, Obama says US reassessing peace approach
entry.summary: But a White House official said Obama also raised Netanyahu's critical comments about Israeli Arabs ahead of the election, which the White House has denounced as a "cynical" effort to mobilize voters.

entry.title: In Netanyahu call, Obama says US reassessing peace approach
entry.summary: But White House spokesman Josh Earnest said Netanyahu's earlier comment "raises questions about his commitment to a two-state solution."

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to "reassess" policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy [Video]
entry.summary:
Obama's telephone call to Netanyahu followed a television interview in which the Israeli leader backed away from his pre-election declaration that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch, an about-face apparently aimed at quelling U.S. criticism triggered by his comments.

An official statement put out later in the day said Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his election win and used the opportunity to reaffirm his commitment to a two-state solution, a longtime cornerstone of U.S. policy on the Middle East conflict.

U.S. officials scolded Netanyahu not only for abandoning his commitment to a Palestinian state but also for his election-day accusation that left-wingers were working to get Israel's minority Arab voters out "in droves" to sway the election.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to 'reassess' policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy
entry.summary: White House spokesman Josh Earnest warned earlier that there would be "consequences" for Israel as the Obama administration monitors the formation of Netanyahu's new ruling coalition.

entry.title: Obama says US to 're-assess' options after Netanyahu win
entry.summary: "They also discussed Prime Minister Netanyahu's comments about Israeli Arabs."

entry.title: Netanyahu denies abandoning two-state solution
Netanyahu backtracks from opposition to Palestinian state
entry.summary: "I don't want a one state solution, I want a sustainable peaceful two state solution but for that circumstances have to change," Netanyahu said.

TEL AVIV (Reuters) - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's main challenger, Zionist Union chief Isaac Herzog, disputed Netanyahu's victory claim in Israel's election on Tuesday, saying "everything is open".

"This result allows us to return to power," Herzog told supporters at party headquarters in Tel Aviv after exit polls showed a tie between the center-left Zionist Union and Netanyahu's right-wing Likud.

entry.title: Israeli candidates on last day of campaign before election to determine Netanyahu's future
entry.summary:
Netanyahu, who has governed for the past six years and has long been the most dominant personality in Israeli politics, has watched his standing plummet in recent weeks.

Tuesday's election caps an acrimonious three-month campaign that is widely seen as a referendum on Netanyahu.

The hard-line leader has portrayed himself as the only politician capable of confronting Israel's numerous security challenges, while his opponents have focused on the country's high cost of living and presented Netanyahu as imperious and out of touch with the common man.

As Netanyahu's poll numbers have dropped in recent days, he has appeared increasingly desperate, stepping up his nationalistic rhetoric in a series of interviews to local media to appeal to his core base.

Netanyahu has also complained of an international conspiracy to oust him, funded by wealthy foreigners who dislike him, and on Sunday night, he addressed an outdoor rally before tens of thousands of hard-line supporters in Tel Aviv.

they estimate the Zionist Union would win between 24 and 26 seats in the 120-seat Knesset, compared to 20-22 seats for Mr Netanyahu's Likud Party.

entry.title: After speech, White House could determine Netanyahu's fate

entry.summary:
Which way it goes for Netanyahu may hinge on whether Israel is in some perceptible way punished by the White House for its leader's extraordinary offensive against a U.S. president.

At home and abroad, Netanyahu is seen by many as a leading obstacle to peace with the Palestinians and perhaps the Arab world.

For this and other reasons, Netanyahu has found himself at increasingly toxic loggerheads with the country's elites - from the security establishment to academics, journalists, cultural figures and much of the business world.

Under these circumstances, while Netanyahu's speech was delivered to the U.S. Congress, his primary audience may well have been Israel's voters half a world away.

But expressing the unease felt by many Jews abroad over such comments, Jair Melchior, Denmark's chief rabbi, said he was "disappointed" by Mr Netanyahu's call.

Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli professor of political science, described Mr Netanyahu's call as "an intellectual and moral mistake" and accused him of taking a populist stance for electoral purposes.
